Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A mandatory pre-shift briefing on new operational procedures is about to start.
Story:
I was halfway through my morning coffee when my phone buzzed—my stepbrother, Sam, was calling. His voice trembled as he told me about the news: our dad’s health had taken a sudden turn for the worse. He needed me, just to talk, to help him process it. I could hear the panic in his words, the way he tried to hold himself together. I wanted nothing more than to stay on the line, to be the sibling he could lean on, just like we’d promised each other after our parents married.

But my watch beeped, reminding me that the pre-shift briefing was about to start. Today’s session was mandatory—new safety protocols, strict attendance, no exceptions. As a subway operator, I was expected to be focused, professional, and present. Missing the briefing could mean disciplinary action, or worse, putting passengers at risk if I missed something crucial.

I stared at the clock, phone pressed to my ear, torn between Sam’s shaky breaths and the echoing call to duty. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—family or work, support or responsibility—knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
